activities.name: BLOCKCHAIN (How authentication & authorisation is done in blockchain space)

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION Cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin and Dogecoin have seized the limelight with spectacular returns for early believers (and well, Elon Musk's tweets), but the real star at the end of the day may very well be the underlying Blockchain technology instead. More than a handful of financial institutions see huge potential in the use of Blockchain, and one of these FI includes our bank. Just April this year, DBS, JP Morgan and Temasek announced a blockchain-based settlement platform, named Partior to facilitate the conduct of real-time cross-border transactions. Do you know what exactly is Blockchain and why is it touted to be a more secure system of recording information? Is there really no way to change, hack, or cheat the system with Blockchain?

dropdownContent.videoName: How does a blockchain work - Simply Explained
dropdownContent.videoText: Check out the video for a succinct introduction to Blockchain.

dropdown.heading: 2. How does a transaction get into blockchain?

dropdownContent.content: Authentication The original blockchain was designed to operate without a central authority (i.e. with no bank or regulator controlling who transacts), but transactions still have to be authenticated. This is done using cryptographic keys, a string of data (like a password) that identifies a user and gives access to their "account" or "wallet" of value on the system. Each user has their own private key and a public key that everyone can see. Using them both creates a secure digital identity to authenticate the user via digital signatures and to "unlock" the transaction they want to perform.

Authorisation Once the transaction is agreed between the users, it needs to be approved, or authorised, before it is added to a block in the chain. For a public blockchain, the decision to add a transaction to the chain is made by consensus. This means that the majority of "nodes" (or computers in the network) must agree that the transaction is valid. The people who own the computers in the network are incentivised to verify transactions through rewards. This process is known as "proof of work".

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.Once a data is recorded inside a blockchain, it becomes difficult to change it because all the blocks are linked together by the hash, or "fingerprint" of its previous block, and changing something in a block will cause its hash to change. As such, hashing ensures the security of the blockchain.
questions.feedback:
<#3ab87a>False</color>
Hash itself is not enough to prevent tampering. High computing power can facilitate the recalculation of hash easily. Hence, it also leverages on algorithm such as proof-of-work as well as the use of distributed ledger concept.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q2.With blockchain, it is impossible to change, hack or cheat the system.
questions.feedback:
<#3ab87a>False</color>
If a group of miners gain control of more than 50% of the network, they can control what is being recorded. This is known as 51% attack.

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION Per the Group Reputational Risk Management Policy, DBS Group's reputation is its most valuable asset and we adopt a zero tolerance mindset for reputational risk that can endanger our franchise. Why are we so uptight about reputation? How exactly does reputational risk come about, and how can we manage it?

dropdown.heading: 1. Why are we so concerned about reputation?

dropdownContent.content:
Boeing's 737 MAX was grounded for 20 months after two high-profile international crashes just five months apart, in Oct 2018 and Mar 2019, saw 346 passengers and crew killed.

This unprecedented aviation fiasco could be attributed to MAX's MCAS. MCAS, or Manoeuvring Characteristics Augmentation System, is an onboard flight-control software designed to tilt the nose of the plane down when it detects that the angle of the ascent is too steep to prevent the plane from stalling.

As it turned out, the badly designed and implemented MCAS was merely the manifestation of a deeper and more insidious cultural issue at Boeing where profit is valued over safety. Damning internal Boeing communications released as part of the investigations showed senior employees having little regard for regulators, customers and even co-workers. "This airplane is designed by clowns, who are in turn supervised by monkeys", an internal communications revealed. In another message by an employee in 2018, "I still haven't been forgiven by God for the covering up I did last year" apparently in reference to interactions with the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA). The grounding of 737 Max is projected to cost a whopping $18 billion. The incident has also left an indelible mark on Boeing's once unblemished reputation - in Axios Harris Poll, Boeing's reputation ranking dropped from #19 in 2019 to #84 in 2020, registering a steep decline of 65 spots. Boeing is certainly a far cry from the engineering marvel it once was.

dropdown.heading: 2. How does reputation risk come about?

dropdownContent.highlightContent: FOOD FOR THOUGHT DBS has won numerous awards in recent years. This would mean that customers would have high expectation of DBS and that we have to work hard to upkeep the Bank's reputation.

dropdownContent.content: DBS adopts a 4-step approach to managing reputational risk - prevent, detect, escalate and respond. Emphasis is on embedding ethical behaviours and sound practices. PRIDE! Value should guide the employees in all their undertakings

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.We should be concerned about reputation risk because?
questions.feedback:
<#3ab87a>All of the above.</color>
Recall the 3Fs of reputation.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q2.Reputation risk comes about because of

options.option: Reputation-reality gap and weak internal coordination
High level of beliefs and expectations
High level of beliefs and expectations and extensive news coverage
Reputation-reality gap, changing beliefs and expectations and weak internal coordination

questions.feedback:
<#3ab87a>Last option</color>
Reputation-reality gap, changing beliefs and expectations and weak internal coordination

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION This relates to the risk event on incorrect processing of sell orders for client shares, where Ops staff failed to investigate and escalate breaks identified during the pre-settlement cash reconciliation, and also made the wrong assumption that the resultant stock holding reconciliation break was due to system issue, eventually resulting in a significant loss.

dropdownContent.content: Case Study In 2018, a retail customer placed an order to sell 2,000 ABC shares with a dealer in SG. The dealer correctly executed the sell order through the trading interface owned by broker but erroneously conveyed it as a Buy order to Ops. The discrepancy was identified during the pre-settlement broker cash reconciliation between internal system and broker records but not followed up. Subsequently, stock holding differences in the weekly stock reconciliation was detected but Ops staff incorrectly assumed that this was due to an (unrelated) system issue at that time and thus no further actions were taken. The break was also not reported in the monthly KRIs. As the break persisted, in Oct 2020, this was escalated to Tech for investigation and the incorrect booking was only discovered then, resulting in a substantial loss in buying back the shortfall in ABC shares.

dropdownContent.highlightContent: Lessons learned: All breaks need to be investigated, reported and escalated to the management timely. No assumptions should be made.

dropdownContent.content:
The case study shows the importance of monitoring breaks and ensuring that the differences are promptly investigated and resolved. In Ops, such breaks in transaction processing as part of key ops risk metrics being monitored. Other categories of metrics being monitored include GL  Account breaks, Internal Account as well as Customer Service.

Let's take a look at the different Transaction Processing Breaks

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.For the Case Study in question, the review of pre-settlement broker cash reconciliation is an example of
<#02caee>Q2.It is important to monitor for breaks to

options.option: Ensure accuracy and completeness of transactions recorded
Ensure accurate reflection of the bank's state of affairs

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q3.All breaks need to be promptly investigated and properly accounted for. Where unsure of the cause of discrepancy, staff should promptly escalate the issue to supervisor. No assumption should be made.

activities.name: Deepfake So what is deepfake? Should it be something that we should be concerned with? Check out this learning and find out for yourself how easy or difficult it is to distinguish between what's real or fake.

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION

introduction.videoName: Deep Fakes - How They’re Made And How They Can Be Detected

introduction.content: A deepfake refers to a specific kind of synthetic media where a person in an image or video is swapped with another person's likeness. In more recent examples, deepfakes can be a voice that sounds like your boss on the other end of a phone line.

dropdownContent.content:
In March 2019, the CEO of a U.K-based energy firm listened over the phone as his boss - the leader of the firm's German parent company - ordered the urgent transfer of €220,000 to a supplier in Hungary. News reports would later detail that the CEO recognized the "<link="https://www.wsj.com/articles/fraudsters-use-ai-to-mimic-ceos-voice-in-unusual-cybercrime-case-11567157402"><u>slight German accent and the melody</u></link>" of his chief's voice and followed the order to transfer the money [equivalent to about $243,000] within an hour.

It turns out that the this was a fraud and it was believed that the thieves used artificial intelligence to create a deepfake of the German executive's voice.
Deepfakes can be very convincing and hard to detect. However, there are certain pointers for one to look out for:
Since seeing and hearing is no longer enough,
Have a healthy dose of scepticism Train your immune system. Always ask: where did the image/ video come from, who is sending this to you etc
Always Validate! For instance, for the case mentioned earlier, one simple mitigating measure would be for the call recipient to hang up and call back.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.Challenge yourself! Can you tell which of these videos are deepfake?
<#02caee>Q2.Challenge yourself! Can you tell which of these videos are deepfake?
<#02caee>Q3.Challenge yourself! Can you tell which of these videos are deepfake?
<#02caee>Q4.Challenge yourself! Can you tell which of these videos are deepfake?
<#02caee>Q5.Challenge yourself! Can you tell which of these videos are deepfake?
<#02caee>Q6.Challenge yourself! Can you tell which of these videos are deepfake?

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION In Feb 2021, there was a federal judge ruling which sent shockwaves through Wall Street - recipients of $900m which Citigroup wired in error need not return the cash. So what was this case about, and why was it significant?

dropdownContent.content:
Citigroup is the administrator of a $1.8 billion term loan for the cosmetics company Revlon and transfer interest due on the loan to the creditors.

On August 11, 2020, Citigroup transferred USD$900m - an amount nearly 100 times greater, to Revlon's creditors by mistakes, paying off the exact full amount of principal and interest from its own funds.

The error was discovered within hours as part of its daily cash reconciliation process. Citigroup asked the creditors to return the funds, and some (fund management houses) refused, disagreeing that there had been a mistake and said the transfer was a repayment of the loan.

Citigroup had to sue the creditors for the return of the funds in US Federal Courts. In Feb 2021, the federal judge ruled that recipients do not have to return the cash.

Recipients of cash wired in error are typically required to return it. But in this case, the creditors had reasonable grounds to believe the payment was intentional, the judge wrote in his ruling. "To believe that Citibank, one of the most sophisticated financial institutions in the world, had made a mistake that had never happened before, to the tune of nearly $1 billion, would have been borderline irrational," he wrote.

(This case is currently pending the outcome of appeal lodged by Citigroup.)
In general, there are 2 types of internal controls - preventive and detective

Both preventive and detective controls are important components of internal controls.

In Citigroup's case, the error was discovered via its detective control of daily cash reconciliation.

However, as the case showed, the axiom "prevention is better than cure" rings true. Once money is out of the bank, there is no guarantee that it will be returned even if the recipient in question is a well regarded fund management house.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.In this Citigroup's case, the payment error occurred as a result of (tick all that is/are applicable)
questions.feedback:
<#3ab87a>A & B</color>
C was one reason why the group of Revlon lenders refused to return the funds, and therefore a circumstance to the risk event, but it did not cause the payment error to occur

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q2.Payment made in error to individuals may not be recoverable, however, if it involves an institution, it will definitely be recoverable.
questions.feedback:
<#3ab87a>False</color>
Once money is out of the bank, there is no guarantee that it will definitely be recoverable

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION You may consider Accounting super boring but do you know that slightly more than 500 years ago, when an Italian monk by the name of Luca Pacioli wrote an instructional section on double-entry bookkeeping in a math encyclopaedia, it was considered revolutionary? Author Jane Gleeson-White explained in her book Double Entry: How the Merchants of Venice Created Modern Finance, "You could itemize the profits in each account, so you knew which products you were doing well in and which you weren't. Then you could start to think about how you would change your business activities. It was just a whole revolution in the way of thinking about business and trade." Of course, the ability to have insights into the business hinges on the accuracy of information that goes into the books. A lot of us in Operations play an important role in presenting a true and fair presentation of the bank's financial statements through posting of MJEs or GLAO certification. So, let's recap on some key accounting concepts!

dropdownContent.content: The central thesis of accounting is that a business is considered a separate entity from its owner(s). Hence, if you put $100 into setting up an ice cream business, your business will have $100 of cash, but also owes you $100 for capital you put in. If you borrow an additional $100 from your friend for the business, your business will now have $200 in cash (Asset) and owes a total of $200 -> $100 to your friend (Liability) and $100 to you as owner (Equity)

dropdownContent.highlightContent: This Accounting equation MUST hold true: Assets = Liabilities + Equity

dropdownContent.content:
<style="H2"><color=#00DAFC>Q.</color> How do revenue and expenses fit into this equation?</style>
Well, just remember that at the end of the day, the Profit & Loss of the business is borne by the owner. So, revenue less expenses (and less whatever you take out from the business, i.e. dividends) feeds into equity eventually.

dropdown.heading: 2. Double Entry Principle & The Nature of Accounts

dropdownContent.content:
<style="H2"><color=#00DAFC>Q.</color>So how exactly do debits and credits work?</style></color>

The following video explains this pretty well!

dropdownContent.videoName: Debits and Credits MADE EASY with ADEx LER
dropdownContent.videoText: Debits and Credits made easy with ADExLER

dropdownContent.content: In gist: 1.Every transaction consists of debit and credit of at least 2 accounts 2.For every transaction, the total amount of debits must equal to the total amount of credits 3.To know whether to post a debit or credit to a particular account, you need to know the nature of the account:

dropdownContent.highlightContent: Remember 1.Understand the need for balance, and know that single entry, double debits, or double credits are a no-no. 2.Know the nature of the account, in order to know whether to post debit or credit.

dropdownContent.content: Other important concept in Accounting got to do with Matching principle and Accrual concept of accounting

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.Which of the following is INCORRECT?

options.option: Debit an Asset will increase the Asset
Credit a Liability will increase the Liability
Credit an Expense will increase the Expense
Credit the Revenue will increase the Revenue

questions.feedback:
<#3ab87a>C</color>
An expense account is DEBIT in nature. Hence, to add to expense, you go along with its nature, i.e. Debit it.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q2.Bank A extends a $100k car loan to Customer B. The correct entry/ entries would be:

options.option: Debit Asset - Car Loan $100k, Credit Asset - Cash $100k
Credit Asset - Car Loan $100k, Debit Asset - Cash $100k
Debit Asset - Car Loan $100k, Debit Asset - Cash $100k

questions.feedback:
<#3ab87a>B</color>
Remember the concept of double-entry where every transaction will have equal and opposite entries (so A & D are no-no). In this case, both accounts are Assets (debit in nature), and you need to determine whether it has increased or decreased. As the Asset-Car loan has increased, it will be a debit entry. As for the Asset- Cash, it has decreased and hence it will be a credit entry.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q3.Bank Z received an upfront fee of $30K for a 3-year syndicated loan. According to the accrual and matching concept and assuming that the fees are recognized evenly across the three years, which of the following is TRUE at the end of Year 1?
questions.feedback:
<#3ab87a>C</color>
Explanation: Although $30K fee was received, $10K has not been earned at the end of Year 1. In accordance with the accrual principle, the income statement will only reflect $10K fee income. The remaining unearned revenue of $20K will be reflected on the balance sheet as a liability as the product has yet to be delivered to the customer.
Accounting entry is as follows: Dr Bank (Asset) 30K Cr Fee income 10K (Revenue) Cr Unearned revenue 20K (Liability).

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION Do you know that phishing scams account for about half of all fraud attacks? Phishing emails tricks the way our brains make decisions so we are all vulnerable to phishing attempts. To safeguard ourselves, it is important to be aware of our mental tendencies and vulnerabilities. Find out more in this short learning!

dropdownContent.content: According to Nobel Prize winning psychologist and economist Daniel Kahneman, humans adopt two systems of thinking, as follows

Because we made thousands of decisions per min, we need (and rely) a lot of System 1 thinking to provide us with mental shortcuts to help us move through life efficiently.

For instance, we have a truth bias, a belief that others are more likely to tell the truth than to lie; to assume otherwise would be exhausting. But biases like this can also leave us open to unwise decisions, such as making us predisposed to assume the authenticity of an email.

Phishing works by trying to get us to stay in System 1, or automatic mode of thinking. In other words, the Phishers want users to make fast instead of thoughtful decisions by manipulating victims via mental shortcuts (also known as cognitive biases). Check out some of these cognitive biases subject to exploitation by phishers.

There is no perfect technology solution to filter out phishing emails, and phishing is not going to go away, just like deception will always be present in the physical world. However, we can adopt the use of shortcuts to trigger System 2 thinking.

Examples:
1.<indent=3%>[Where] Is it an email from an external source - [External] tag?</indent>
2.<indent=3%>[Who] Do I know the sender?</indent>
3.<indent=3%>[What] is the mail trying to influence me or playing with my emotion (e.g. offer, urgency)?</indent>
4.<indent=3%>[How] Does it have a link or attachment? Does it request for your personal information?</indent>

dropdownContent.highlightContent: Remember: It only takes one click to get hooked!

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION This learning seeks to address common misconceptions about UDMA and UDMA identification. P.S. If you have not heard of UDMA at all, UDMA stands for User Developed and/or Managed Application (basically, it relates to tools/applications developed and/or managed by users without IT support). You should also check out the e-learning on UDMA at DBS Learning Hub or ask OneBot. UDMA is a 4-letter word that all Operations folks should know!

dropdownContent.content: <style="H2">1.<indent=4%>Important! There can be operational risks to creating and using your own tool.</indent></style>

<style="H2">2.<indent=4%>If true "kiasu", everything would have been scoped in, but that's not the case...</style></indent>

We operate on risk-based approach and include only those non-IT developed/managed tools/ applications used to support on-going operations with regulatory, financial, customer impact or for critical risk reporting.

<style="H2">3.<indent=4%>Hey, UDMA is not a bad word...</style></indent>

Ok, we know that when a tool is identified as a UDMA, there are requirements like getting approval, reviewing the controls and lodging it. But this is meant to ensure visibility of such tools used in the bank and prioritisation of IT resourcing for automation. It is also to minimise operational risks over the tool development and maintenance process.

dropdownContent.highlightContent: Remember, we can be blind to our own mistakes. (Hey, even Intelligence agents made seemingly simple mistake!)

dropdownContent.content: Be on the Lookout! Use the 3 pointers below to help you assess if something should be considered as UDMA

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.I am using a tool/application that is developed by my colleague to improve efficiency in the operational process.

options.option: Nothing to worry about. After all, it's all for efficiency gain
If it can have customer/regulatory/ financial impact, I should check if it has been/ needs to be lodged as UDMA
It should be fine. The tool has been in used for as long as I can remember.

questions.feedback:
<#3ab87a>B</color>
Ans A: Incorrect. As highlighted, there can be operational risks from the use of the tool and further assessment needs to be made.
Ans C: Incorrect. Do not assume. If unsure, please check with your team lead

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION Some of you may think that policies are torturous, but really these set out principles which are meant to steer behaviour in making decisions towards achieving company goals. Do you know that in the bank, the term "Policy & Standard" is but a generic term used to describe a suite of documents to guide staff in their conduct and operations? Find out more in this learning!

dropdownContent.highlightContent: Do You Know? DBS established a bankwide Policy Architecture since Nov 2014, that is simple to understand and applied consistently across the Group.

dropdownContent.content: 1.Easy! In Intranet homepage, under the 'Tools & Resources' tab, look for the 'Business Policies' section and click on 'Policy Repository'. 2.Or... just click on the DBS Policy Repository link and bookmark this.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.In the DBS Policy Repository, search for the T&O Risk Approval Process document (hint: search by document name). Paste the URL here.
<#02caee>Q2.In the DBS Policy Repository, search for the T&O Risk Approval Process document (hint: search by document name). Indicate whether this is a Mandate, Policy, Standard or Guide.

introduction.highlightContent: Do You Know? (1)The WFH protocol was first established in April 2021 based on existing policies and standards and with the underlying practices embedded in our daily operations. (2)Given the current pandemic situation and with many of us still working from home, it is timely that we have a refresher of the Dos and Don'ts.

dropdownContent.content: Dos (1)Find a quiet spot in your home where you won't be distracted and where DBS information and devices can be kept safe. (2)Use a private and secured Wi-Fi network you know and trust.

Dos (1)Always use DBS-issued laptop for business purpose only. (2)Always use our internal messaging systems (MS Teams or DBS email) or official work number to contact your colleagues. (3)Stick to established process & controls. (4)If you notice anything amiss, escalate to your manager ASAP.

Don'ts (1)Take photos or videos of info on your laptop screen. (2)Send corporate emails to personal email accounts. (3)Download DBS info onto external device. (4)Upload DBS info onto external website or cloud-based storage. (5)Divulge sensitive DBS info or username-password combinations if you receive any unexpected emails/calls. Report suspicious emails/calls to CERT@dbs.com (6)Let your family members look over your shoulder when you're working or hear your work conversations. (7)Schedule personal appointments during working hours. You should take leave instead.
Dos Always lock your laptop.
Don'ts Leave physical DBS materials lying around.

Dos (1)Regularly communicate with your managers and team on work progress. (2)Inform your manager and BCM coordinator if you are unwell. (3)Abide by all safe management guidelines issued by the local authorities and the Bank. (4)Report any loss/ theft of IT equipment as soon as possible.
Don'ts Don't respond to any media queries on your own. Always direct them to GSMC.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.You have just completed a prototype of a Tableau dashboard and cannot wait to show to your team to share the good news, especially since you have spent many hours working on the prototype. You quickly take a photo on your mobile phone and shared it on WhatsApp Messenger with the rest of the team.

options.option: This is fine since there is dynamic watermarking. We must always celebrate success!
This is not allowed.  You should never take photos or videos of info on your laptop screen.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q2.You have been in back-to-back meetings since morning and only have a 30-minute window period for lunch. Before you leave your desk and dash off for a quick bite, you should first (tick all that is/are applicable)

options.option: Tell your teammates or manager via MS TEAMS to let them know you will be away from your desk.
Put away any physical company documents and not leave them lying around.
Block your calendar, so that no one disturbs you during your lunch.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q3.If I can work from home, I can work from anywhere, be it a cafe or anywhere with a good Wi-Fi signal.

options.option: This is fine, so long as I can meet my deliverables.
This is not allowed.  Remote work is confined to the home environment (in a WFH arrangement) or satellite office in view of data leakage risks.

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION 'Offline Billing' is a term we used within Ops to refer to billing processes that are not automated. Find out more in this learning, the risks involved in a billing process, and how these risks can be mitigated.

dropdown.heading: 2. Risk and Controls in Billing Process

dropdownContent.content: In the previous section, we indicated that there's risks in each step of the billing process. So what are these risks, and how can these be mitigated?

dropdownContent.highlightContent: Billing Processes are to be Approved on Exception Basis (1)All business and automation options have been exhausted (2)BU must accept the risks for billings to be done offline (3)Approval must be sought from T&O Senior Management in accordance with T&O Risk Approval Process (4)Review must be done yearly and if to remain, re-approval must be sought

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.When is the billing process considered as "Offline Billing"

options.option: When the "Initiate Billing/ Maintain Billing Schedule" is not automated
When the "Calculation of Billing Amount" is not automated
When the "Billing Data Generation" is not automated
When the "Payment Tracking" is not automated
Either of A, B, C or D above

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q2.As long as we put in place the necessary controls, we can proceed to do Offline Billing

options.option: True, as long as controls are in place, it's fine
False. All Offline Billing are to be approved on an exception basis

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION Thank you for participating in BRING PROMI HOME program. But have you ever wondered what "PROMI" actually stands for (beyond the cute penguin mascot)?

introduction.highlightContent: Do You Know? PROMI is actually the acronym of the 5 Key Risk Principles introduced in T&O back in 2019. What are the 5 Key Risk Principles? Watch the video below to find out more!

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.What does PROMI stand for?

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION 5W1H stands for "Who, What, When, Where, Why and How", and is used as a structured approach to think about problem-solving. Check out this e-learning to learn more about 5W1H and how it is used.

dropdownContent.highlightContent: Do You Know? 5W1H method is also known as the Kipling method and was coined after the poem by Rudyard Kipling which appeared in "Just So Stories" published in 1902.

dropdownContent.content: Read the extract of the poem below.

dropdownContent.highlightContent: Take a moment to ponder Now that you are an adult, do you still keep the six honest serving-men working for you, or have they "retired" from your life? P.S. Rudyard Kipling was an English journalist, short-story writer, poet, and novelist. You may have heard of "The Jungle Book". Well, he was the author!

dropdownContent.content:
Essentially, 5W1H is used to think about various aspects of any problem so that a comprehensive solution can be devised. It is useful tool to employ when you are designing or redesigning a process.

Let's look at what each of these component stand for:
Do you know that 5W1H is flexible enough to use in all kinds of situations? Try applying this 5W1H to a meeting today!

dropdownContent.highlightContent: Why Why is the meeting necessary?
What What problem are you trying to solve? What information/ feedback do you need to solicit?
Who Who may have the expertise/ information relevant for the discussion? Who are affected and who do you need to obtain buy-in?
When When are all the critical stakeholders available? Have you sort out the necessary information to have the meeting
Where Should the conversation be held over email or over Webex? Should a workshop be organised?
How How should you structure the conversation? (How about using 5W1H!)

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.Match the 5W1H component to its description 1. Steps/ Procedures 2. Issue 3. People 4. Location/ Business Practices 5. Purpose 6. Time/ Sequence

activities.name: Data Privacy and Responsible Use of Data

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION Have you ever logged into Facebook and got creeped out when you see that Facebook has suggested one of your colleagues as a "friend", even though you have not added any colleague as a "friend", and there is no apparent links like common friends or part of the same alumni? Or does it make your hair stand to know that "On average, it is enough to know the 5 locations that you routinely visit during a day - your home, your workplace, the gym you go to, the restaurant you go for dinner, the school where you dropped off your child - to identify you among everyone on Earth", & that knowing 8 friends on social media also makes a unique YOU(1)? Indeed, with the leap in computing power and the advancement of machine learning and artificial intelligent, there is increasing concern over how personal data are collected, used and shared. Recognising this, the bank has set out principles to ensure that the bank collect, use, disclose and protect Personal Data in a respectful, responsible and reasonable manner. Let's learn more about this in this learning! (1) Assistant Professor Reza Shokri, NUS Presidential Young Professor of Computer Science. Source: Channel News Asia

dropdownContent.content: The Group Privacy <link="http://megaweb1.sgp.dbs.com/advisor/policyrepository/documents/DBS-08-P-0003-GR-Group-Privacy-Policy.pdf"><u>Policy</u></link> and <link="http://megaweb1.sgp.dbs.com/advisor/policyrepository/documents/DBS-08-S-0036-GR-Group-Privacy-Standard.pdf"><u>Standard</u></link> set out the requirements and controls by which the bank collect, use, disclose and protect Personal Data in a respectful, responsible and reasonable manner, in line with regulatory requirements.

Remember the Facebook - Cambridge Analytica data scandal where personal data of millions of Facebook users were obtained and used without their consent for purpose of targeted political campaign?

As more and more people become more concerned about how and why institutions collect and use their data, it is no longer about just "whether it can be done" (legally permissible, technical feasibility), but importantly, "should it be done" (ethically)?

Here's where our P.U.R.E guiding principles come into play to ensure that data is used responsibly

For more details, please see <link="http://megaweb1.sgp.dbs.com/advisor/policyrepository/documents/DBS-13-S-0006-GR-Responsible-Data-Use---PURE-Standard.pdf"><u>Responsible Data Use Standard</u></link>

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.I have access to customer information database, and I decided to use it to find the contact details of some old school friends.

options.option: No problem. I am just trying to reconnect with old friends.
False. Access to Personal Data is strictly on a need-to-know basis for work purpose.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q2.Do you agree with the following statement - We only need to ensure compliance with relevant law and regulation for the use of data.

options.option: No. In addition to complying with law and regulation, we also need to ensure that data is used responsibly in line with PURE framework.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q3.PURE stands for?

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION Risk assessment may sound profound, but do you know you do it all the time? For example, every time you get into a car and go onto the road, there is risk involved. However, you would have considered the risk, determined that the benefits outweighs the risk, and also implement mitigating measures such as putting on a seatbelt. See, not such a difficult concept isn’t it? Risk assessment, at its heart, is just a structured way of thinking to deal with the many different risks that we faced everyday. The basic steps consist of identifying the risks, assessing the risks, examining the alternatives and the mitigating measures to determine your response. Let’s go through each of these steps using simple examples.

dropdownContent.content: Asking "What Could Go Wrong" Risk assessment starts, first of all, with an active consideration of things that can go wrong. It can come with drawing on your experience, the experience of others, and actively adopting a more deliberate thought process. As psychologist Nathaniel Branden said, "the first step towards change is awareness." Hence, it all starts with being a little bit more aware, and to exercise the use of System 2 thinking more often.

dropdownContent.highlightContent: What is this System 2 thinking? Basically, Nobel Prize winner in economics Daniel Kahneman said there are 2 decision-making systems. One is System 1 – fast, intuitive and takes little effort. System 2 is analytical but is slower and also energy consuming and hence, human’s tendency is to use system 1 over system 2.

dropdownContent.content:
Let’s say I offer you $100 you to walk on a tightrope that is about 30cm off the ground. You will most likely accept my offer.

What if the tightrope is 2m off the ground. Would you still do it?

Now, the probability of falling is the same, but obviously you would think twice about the 2nd scenario because the consequence of a fall would be more severe. You could probably break a limb!

But, what if there’s a safety net beneath the tightrope? Would you now change your mind?

dropdownContent.highlightContent: So in evaluating the risks, you consider both The likelihood that something will go wrong AND the severity of the consequence

dropdownContent.content: With a good understanding of the risks involved in an activity, you can now evaluate the different options available.

<style="H2">Avoidance</style>
Not to proceed with the activity
(Maybe going on tightrope for $100 isn’t quite worth it?)

<style="H2">Transference</style>
Getting 3rd party to bear the risk
(How about getting an insurance in place?)

<style="H2">Mitigation</style>
Reduce the probability and/or severity of the risk
(Perhaps you can lobby for additional safety harness?)

<style="H2">Acceptance</style>
Accepting the risks involved
(Hey, you may want to inform your parent/partner first!)

dropdownContent.highlightContent: Concluding thoughts... After going through these 3 steps, you may ask, “isn’t this but common sense thinking?” Well, you are right! The crux is simply being more conscious of your thought process so that your decision can be a more informed one.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.Risk assessment is a specialised field practised by professional risk managers.

options.option: True. Professional risk managers possess the necessary knowledge and tool to perform proper risk assessment.
False. Everyone can conduct risk assessment.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q2.In assessing the risk of an activity, one should only focus on the consequence that can result from an activity.

options.option: False. Besides consequence, one should also consider the likelihood that something will go wrong.

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION We mentioned in the topic of Basic Accounting that a lot of us in Operations play an important role in presenting a true and fair presentation of the bank’s financial statements. One key detective control in ensuring the integrity of the bank’s financial statements is GLAO (General Ledger Account Ownership). This learning recaps some key highlights of GLAO as well as some common mistakes. If you are not already a GLAO reconciler or owner, you may want to read on to find out more too … who knows, it may be a role you need to perform in future!

dropdownContent.content: In Scope On Balance Sheet accounts (Monthly) Off Balance Sheet accounts (Quarterly) This includes any on/off Balance sheet accounts with zero balances at month-end but with transactions during the month

Key Task Reconcile and substantiate each balance to a verifiable independent external source(s) Acceptable sources include:- 1.External source (e.g. invoices from brokers and custodian statements) 2.Source system generated reports (e.g. Murex) can be used if there are controls in place surrounding the accuracy and validity of the report.
Basically, GLAO certification is reporting the “result” after reviewing the GLAO balances. There are a few scenarios that the result can fall into.

<style="H2">1.<indent=5%>Inappropriate Source Report Used</style>
Inappropriate source report used for substantiating ledger balances including
i.<indent=8%>using GL report from Finance</indent>
ii.<indent=8%>internally maintained spreadsheets/ reports without validation with external supporting documents.

dropdownContent.highlightContent:
<indent=7%><voffset=2em><size=25><sprite=3></voffset></size><indent=18%>Remember that the purpose is to verify the ledger balances.

If we use internal sources such as PSGL balances, then it would be a case of circular reference error!

dropdownContent.content:
<style="H2">2.<indent=5%>Incorrect Understanding of Rounding Difference (CAT 0)</style>
Rounding difference” is used loosely in many instances. Note that "Rounding difference" is strictly due to system truncation of decimal places only.

<style="H2">3.<indent=5%>Incorrect Understanding of Timing Difference (CAT 1)</style>
CAT 1 is to be used for reconciliation differences relating to timing differences which will be <u>cleared automatically</u> within the next few days.

It <u>does not</u> include
i.<indent=8%>rectification journals posted via MJE within the next few days after month end</indent>
ii.<indent=8%>Entries (e.g. accruals) erroneously omitted within the month and subsequently posted few days after the month end.</indent>
iii.<indent=8%>Breaks pending investigation

dropdownContent.highlightContent: <indent=6%><voffset=6em><size=20><sprite=7></voffset></size><indent=15%><voffset=2.7em>Just remember, if it requires intervention to clear the difference, then it will not be CAT1

dropdownContent.content:
<style="H2">4.<indent=5%>Aged Balances not Certified as CAT 4B</style>
Overdue balances exceeding 30 days from contractual date not flagged.

dropdownContent.highlightContent: <indent=3%><voffset=1em><size=30><sprite=2></voffset></size><indent=10%>If you recall, one objective of GLAO is to ensure that asset and liability balances reflected on the balance sheet are appropriate. For example, a long outstanding Accounts Receivable may not be recoverable and a provision should be recognised.

dropdownContent.content:
<style="H2">5.<indent=5%>Clearing Account Balances not Cleared at Month-End</style>
Clearing account is used to record transactions of a temporary nature that are to be transferred to another account.

dropdownContent.highlightContent:
<indent=3%><size=25><sprite=1></size><indent=10%>If there are <u>balances not cleared at month-end, to investigate at transactional level and classify accordingly other than CAT 0.</u>

Uncleared entries must be aged and analysed.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.•Reconciler substantiated the ledger balances using a GL report from Finance listing all the GL entries and journals posted for the month •No reconciling differences were identified and the account was signed off as CAT 0 : No reconciliation differences Which statement is True?

options.option: The GL report is an appropriate source and reconciliation can be performed against the monthly movements in the account.

The GL report is not an appropriate source and the ledger balance should be reconciled to total outstanding month-end balances of an independent source which is either an external statement or an internal source system report.

questions.feedback:
1.GLAO reconciliation should be performed on month-end outstanding balance. 
2.The GL report is not an independent source as the ledger balance will always match the balance shown in the GL report!
3.Reconciliation must be performed against an independent source which is either an external statement or an internal source system report.  Where an internal source report is relied on to perform the substantiation there must be adequate controls to ensure that the report is complete and accurate.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q2.As at March month-end, $100 sits in the Clearing account. •This was identified to be a waiver for handling commission, but the entry DR Handling Commission and CR Clearing was not performed yet as at month-end. •The entry was posted on 10th April before the GLAO deadline. How should this account be signed off?

options.option: CAT 3 : Profit and Loss Impact - As this is a waiver of handling commission (income) there is a P&L impact.
CAT 1 : Timing - Operations resolved the difference by posting the entry to write off the fee waiver the following month within 30 days of March month-end

questions.feedback: Although the entry to post the waiver of the handling commission was made within a few days after month-end to resolve the differences, as the entry hit the P&L, the difference should be signed off as CAT 3 - Profit & Loss Impact

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q2.Internal reports are used for GLAO reconciliation for Nets transactions. There is a separate reconciliation process between internal reports and NETs reports. However, breaks noted during the reconciliation is not considered when performing GLAO certification Which of the following statement is correct?

options.option: Internal report should never be used

Internal report can be used if there is a separate reconciliation process between the internal report and external NETS report. However, any reconciliation breaks against NETs statement should be considered in GLAO certification.

introduction.content:
We often rely a lot on what we see as the truth. But can we really trust what we see all the time?

Let’s find out for yourself!

dropdownContent.videoText: Follow the instruction in this video

Did you see the gorilla in the previous video?
Now, check out this 2nd video.

dropdownContent.content: Did you see the gorilla in the 2nd video? What about noticing the colour-changing curtain or the player wearing black leaving the scene?
The 'Invisible Gorilla' (1st video) and 'Monkey Business Illusion' (2nd video) were part of a famous experiment by psychologists Daniel Simons and Christopher Chabris.

The experiment showed that when people are so focused on something, they can become blind to the unexpected, even if they are staring right at it. This is what was coined as "inattentional blindness".

The main point of the experiment is to show that we are less aware of our world that we think.  There may be important things staring right at you but you aren’t noticing it.

dropdownContent.highlightContent: So, What Now? Unfortunately, there isn’t a panacea that will solve this. However, by being more aware of ‘invisible gorillas’ in our lives, we know that we cannot assume that we are seeing whatever there is to see. Some possible avenues to consider - use technology to aid you where possible, get someone else to validate your belief, challenge your own assumptions, and try not to pick up calls when driving for when you multi-task, something may be missed!

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.Did you see the gorilla in the 1st video (Part 1)?
questions.feedback: There's no right or wrong answer!

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.Tell us what you noticed in the 2nd video (Part 2)

options.option: A gorilla, colour-changing curtain, and player wearing black leaving the scene

questions.feedback: There's no right or wrong answer!

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION We frequently talk about controls, controls. But what exactly are we trying to achieve? In this learning, let’s learn a little more about controls

dropdownContent.content:
An effective system of internal controls is important to
1.<indent=3%>Minimise opportunities for unintentional errors or intentional fraud (preventive controls); and</indent>
2.<indent=3%>Discover errors before they become bigger problems (detective controls)</indent>

Internal controls should be instituted based on risk-oriented approach. It is important to note that internal controls not only protect an organisation, but also staff!

Let’s look at some of the common control objectives.

Let’s say you run a little non-profit animal shelter. To raise funds for the operations, you decided to run a 1-month donation drive. You printed some banners, and ask your staff to reach out to all visitors to the shelter. Any donation is placed in a small brown donation box placed at the counter, and donation received is to be deposited into the shelter’s bank account.

What could go wrong? What are some of the questions you may think of?

dropdownContent.highlightContent: Risk: How do I prevent fraud and theft of donation funds?
<margin=3%><voffset=2.8em><sprite=4></voffset><indent=5%><voffset=1.02em>How much was donated?

<margin=3%><voffset=1.4em><sprite=5></voffset><indent=5%>How to ensure security of the donation box?
Who can have access to open the donation box?

<margin=3%><voffset=0.3em><sprite=6></voffset><indent=5%>How to ensure that total amt counted = total donations received?
When should the donations be counted and deposited into the bank (at the end of each day or other regular intervals)?
<margin=3%><voffset=1.5em><sprite=8></voffset><indent=5%><voffset=1.02em>Were the donations properly recorded in the system?

<margin=3%><sprite=9><indent=5%>How much was deposited?
Was it the same as what's collected?
Was it deposited to the right account?

dropdown.heading: 3. Controls to be put in place

dropdownContent.content: Determine the control objectives you want to achieve and the corresponding controls that need to be put in place. Now let’s take a look at some of the controls you should consider putting in place for the animal shelter donation drive.

dropdownContent.highlightContent: The design of internal control is only the beginning of the story… Internal control is effective only when properly designed and operating as intended. Internal controls put in place may not be properly performed, and the processes and procedures for which the controls were designed for may change. As such , it is important to monitor the effectiveness of the internal controls over time to ensure that your control objectives are achieved.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.The purpose of internal control is to protect an organisation against fraud.

options.option: False. Internal controls not only protect the organisation, but staff as well, against both intentional fraud and unintentional errors

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q2.As long as you put in place a set of controls in line with your control objectives, you can rest assured that operational risks will be minimised.

options.option: False. Effectiveness of internal controls is a function of both design effectiveness and operating effectiveness. As such, there is a need to monitor the effectiveness of the controls to ensure that your control objectiveness are achieved.

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION We hope you enjoy your quest to "Bring PROMI Home". Give us your valuable feedback and help us in planning future PROMI journeys! Note: Please check out the PROMI activity tile first to learn more about “PROMI” and what it represents. Do try out more activity tiles to find out what we have in store for you before filling out this feedback.

INTRODUCTION Risk is Everyone's business, and everyone can play a part in creating a Positive Risk Culture in DBS. If you have ever wondered: 1.Why is positive risk culture important in DBS? 2.How can we shape the risk culture in DBS? 3.What risk attitudes and behaviours would support a positive risk culture? Watch the video to find out more!

introduction.videoContent: Why is strong risk culture important in DBS?

dropdownContent.content: What is Risk Culture? Our attitudes towards risk shape our risk related behaviour and forms our risk culture.

carousel.heading: Attitude shapes behaviour
carousel.content: 1.Be guided by our PRIDE! values 2.Beware of key risks and what can go wrong 3.Always do the right thing 4.Uphold Honesty | Fairness | Integrity | Professionalism

carousel.heading: Behaviour forms culture
carousel.content: 1.Abide by DBS Code of Conduct 2.Speak Up on activity which is dishonest, illegal or unethical 3.Build good risk sense by questioning out-of-norm occurrences

carousel.heading: Culture Influences Attitudes and Behaviours
carousel.content:
1.<indent=4%>Tone from the Top sets the moral compass of DBS</indent>
2.<indent=4%>Accountability for actions</indent>
3.<indent=4%>Open and constructive engagement</indent>
4.<indent=4%>Incentives aligned with prudent risk-taking

dropdownContent.highlightContent: "A positive risk culture is one where everyone at every level appropriately manages risk as an intrinsic part of their day-to-day work."

dropdownContent.content:
<style="H2">How can we build risk sense?</style>

In DBS, we expect you to be decisive and take ownership for your actions. Underpinning this is the assumption that the decisions you make will be ethical and based on good risk sense.

You may encounter situations where you are unsure of the appropriate action to take. Use the questions in the diagram below to build your risk sense and develop good judgement to make the right decisions.

questions.ques: <#02caee>Q1.What does the ABC of Risk Culture stand for?
<#02caee>Q1.Which Risk Sense question should you ask yourself in Stage 2 - Identify and Assess the Risk

options.option: What do I observe in DBS?
What is the impact to our customers, employees or the bank?
Who should I discuss the matter with?

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION Did you know there are various portals available in DBS that can help you in understanding risk? Do you know all of them? Click on the links below and bookmark them where necessary!

dropdown.heading: 1. A list of portals that may assist you:

dropdownContent.highlightContent:
<color=#FF8040><style="H2"><u><link="https://dbs1bank.sharepoint.com/sites/tnonpahub">T&O ORR/NPA Portal</link></u></style></color>

Not sure how to begin your NPA/ORR Journey? Need to find the key contact? Use this one stop shop for everything related to NPA/ORR for T&O.

<color=#FF8040><style="H2"><u><link="https://dbs1bank.sharepoint.com/sites/RDU/SitePages/HomePage.aspx">Responsible Data Use</link></u></style></color>

DBS’ Responsible Data Use Framework covers 3 broad dimensions by which we can help ensure that our data are used responsibly. Click to learn more!

<color=#FF8040><style="H2"><u><link="https://dbsspeakup.com/website.aspx?ClientUrl=&Pg=1">DBS Speak Up</link></u></style></color>

If you have knowledge of or encountered a situation that you think is considered suspicious activity, relates to possible staff misconduct, internal fraud, and would like to report the matter, please use this site.

<color=#FF8040><style="H2"><u><link="https://cybrfit.corp.dbs.com:8443/dashboard.xhtml">Cybrfit</link></u></style></color>

#CYBRFIT is a user centric security companion app that measures an individual’s cyber hygiene by collecting the staff’s security vitals from email, web surfing, device, training & awareness. Use this to refresh your knowledge on information security!

<color=#FF8040><style="H2"><u><link="https://dbs1bank.sharepoint.com/sites/sggroupbcm/Pages/Welcome.aspx">GBCM Portal</link></u></style></color>

Want to get latest bank directives to Business Continuity management, including pandemic updates? Go to this portal now!

<color=#FF8040><style="H2"><u><link="https://dbs1bank.sharepoint.com/sites/grouptno/tnocentral2/SitePages/home.aspx">T&O Central</link></u></style></color>

Your one-stop portal to all things T&O, with digital assets, newsletters, Senior Leaders Connect and many more!

introduction.content: INTRODUCTION Often it is not a "Single Root Cause" that is solely responsible for a risk event, but a myriad of contributing factors which needs to be considered and addressed. Contributing Factors Analysis (CFA) methodology is a simple and structured methodology in analysing risk events. Developed in 2019 in collaboration with Kepner-Tregoe, CFA is used in risk event analysis to give a more holistic view of all possible causes to an event. The objective of this tile is to give you a quick summary of the CFA methodology.

dropdownContent.content: On a wet, rainy Friday afternoon, Ben was rushing home in his 3-year-old Lancer to avoid peak hour traffic and to catch his favourite TV Show. As it was a straight road, Ben started to pay attention to the cat video which his friend send to him on his mobile device. Suddenly, the vehicle in front of him applied brakes. Ben got a shock and tried applying brakes as well, but the wet road conditions and his worn out tyres caused his car to skid and crashed into the car in front. Both cars were damaged and Ben has to pay $1000 in repairs.
Conventional Root Cause: Ben’s oversight Conventional Solution: Send Ben back to driving school
CFA is a systematic process to visually describe an incident, and consists of 5 main steps:
Now, let us revisit Ben’s car accident using CFA.
